abstract: With the final approval of financial regulatory reform, banks have moved quickly to turn the rules to their advantage by adding new fees and revamping their derivatives operations.
snippet: With the final approval of financial regulatory reform, banks have moved quickly to turn the rules to their advantage by adding new fees and revamping their derivatives operations.
lead_paragraph: The ink is not even dry on the new rules for Wall Street, and already, the bankers are a step ahead of everyone else.

headline.main: Banks Seek to Keep Profits as New Oversight Rules Loom
headline.print_headline: Cut Back, Banks See a Chance to Grow

byline.original: By Eric Dash and Nelson D. Schwartz

abstract: In an encouraging sign, almost a third of JPMorgan’s second-quarter profit came from a $1.5 billion gain on releasing reserves for loan losses.
snippet: In an encouraging sign, almost a third of JPMorgan’s second-quarter profit came from a $1.5 billion gain on releasing reserves for loan losses.
lead_paragraph: Don’t count on a rebound in business to lift bank stocks — but they might not need it. That’s the message to glean from JPMorgan’s second-quarter results. Granted, the bank’s performance was hardly disastrous, especially considering the recent slowdown in trading across the industry. But almost a third of the bank’s profit came from a $1.5 billion gain on releasing reserves for loan losses.

headline.main: An Encouraging Sign in Loan Loss Reserves
headline.print_headline: An Encouraging Sign in Loan Loss Reserves

abstract: The ink is not even dry on the new rules for Wall Street, and already the bankers are a step ahead of everyone else.

headline.main: Banks Seek to Keep Profits as New Oversight Rules Loom

abstract: The markets struggled to gain ground on Thursday amid economic worries and concerns about the effects of legislation that Congress passed governing on the financial sector.
snippet: The markets struggled to gain ground on Thursday amid economic worries and concerns about the effects of legislation that Congress passed governing on the financial sector.
lead_paragraph: The markets struggled to gain ground on Thursday amid economic worries and concerns about the effects of legislation that Congress passed governing on the financial sector, The New York Times’s Christine Hauer reported.

headline.main: Shares Struggle on Weak Manufacturing Data

abstract: Bank of America on Friday reported $3.1 billion in profits for its second quarter, roughly flat from last year as the firm cited lower credit costs to offset diminished trading profits.
snippet: Bank of America on Friday reported $3.1 billion in profits for its second quarter, roughly flat from last year as the firm cited lower credit costs to offset diminished trading profits.
lead_paragraph: Bank of America on Friday reported $3.1 billion in profits for its second quarter, roughly flat from last year as the firm cited lower credit costs to offset diminished trading profits.

headline.main: Bank of America Beats Profit Estimates

abstract: Citigroup on Friday reported a $2.7 billion profit for its second quarter, its second consecutive quarterly profit, but the firm acknowledged some slowdown in its markets activities.
snippet: Citigroup on Friday reported a $2.7 billion profit for its second quarter, its second consecutive quarterly profit, but the firm acknowledged some slowdown in its markets activities.
lead_paragraph: 9:29 a.m. | Updated The New York Times’s Eric Dash has more on Citigroup’s second-quarter profits.

headline.main: Citi’s Profit Falls as Trading Slows

abstract: Fears of a European debt crisis and a double-dip recession here hurt Citigroup’s investment bank in the quarter.
snippet: Fears of a European debt crisis and a double-dip recession here hurt Citigroup’s investment bank in the quarter.
lead_paragraph: Profit fell at Citigroup and Bank of America in the second quarter as weak trading results overshadowed the benefit they received from dwindling losses on loans to consumers and businesses.

headline.main: Poor Trading Results Take Toll on Profits at Both Citigroup and Bank of America
headline.print_headline: Poor Trading Results Take Toll on Profits At Both Citigroup and Bank of America

abstract: While Bank of America’s chief executive struck an upbeat tone on Friday, he cautioned that some elements in the economy may continue to negatively affect the firm.
snippet: While Bank of America’s chief executive struck an upbeat tone on Friday, he cautioned that some elements in the economy may continue to negatively affect the firm.
lead_paragraph: 9:24 a.m. | Updated While Bank of America‘s second-quarter results beat analysts’ estimates, investors appeared to be more pessimistic about what the prospects of the firm in a more uncertain economic environment.

headline.main: Bank of America’s Chief Sounds Cautious Note

abstract: Bank of America took more than a few analysts and investors by surprise on Friday by disclosing that the pending financial regulatory overhaul may cost the firm $10 billion or more.
snippet: Bank of America took more than a few analysts and investors by surprise on Friday by disclosing that the pending financial regulatory overhaul may cost the firm $10 billion or more.
lead_paragraph: Bank of America took more than a few analysts and investors by surprise on its earnings call Friday by disclosing that the pending financial regulatory overhaul may cost the firm $10 billion or more.

headline.main: New Card Rules May Cost BofA Billions in Revenue

abstract: Senator Ted Kaufman argues that the Goldman Sachs settlement proves that regulators can rein in Wall Street from its excesses and manipulations.
snippet: Senator Ted Kaufman argues that the Goldman Sachs settlement proves that regulators can rein in Wall Street from its excesses and manipulations.
lead_paragraph: Senator Ted Kaufman, Democrat of Delaware, argues that the Goldman Sachs settlement proves that regulators can rein in Wall Street from its excesses and manipulations.

headline.main: Another View: A Victory for the Rule of Law

abstract: Vikram S. Pandit, Citigroup’s chief executive, sounded rather upbeat on Friday about his bank’s ability to absorb losses in revenue caused by the new financial regulations passed by Congress.
snippet: Vikram S. Pandit, Citigroup’s chief executive, sounded rather upbeat on Friday about his bank’s ability to absorb losses in revenue caused by the new financial regulations passed by Congress.
lead_paragraph: Vikram S. Pandit, Citigroup’s chief executive, sounded rather upbeat on Friday about his bank’s ability to absorb losses in revenue caused by the new financial regulations passed by Congress, in contrast to the feelings of heavy concern at rival banks like JPMorgan Chase and Bank of America.

headline.main: Pandit Says Citigroup Can Absorb Curbs on Fees
